title: Part A
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not calculate the total revenue of producing 40 units as $6400 and/or does not show the work.

Total Revenue = Price×Quantity=$160×40=$6,400 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@5E55@

The response calculates the total revenue of producing 40 units as $6400 and shows the work.

Total Revenue = Price×Quantity=$160×40=$6,400 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@5E55@

title: Part B
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that the demand curve is inelastic for quantities between 160 and 180 units and/or does not explain that the marginal revenue is negative; or use numbers to explain that total revenue is falling as the price declines in that quantity range, the percentage change in quantity demanded is less than the percentage change in price, or the absolute value of the price elasticity of demand is less than 1.

The response states that the demand curve is inelastic for quantities between 160 and 180 units and explains that the marginal revenue is negative; or uses numbers to explain that total revenue is falling as the price declines in that quantity range, the percentage change in quantity demanded is less than the percentage change in price, or the absolute value of the price elasticity of demand is less than 1.

title: Part C
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that the firm should increase its price and/or does not explain that at a price of $100 the marginal cost is greater than the marginal revenue or explain that the profit-maximizing price is $140 (this is the price from the demand curve for the profit-maximizing quantity of 60 units where marginal cost is equal to marginal revenue).

The response states that the firm should increase its price and explains that at a price of $100 the marginal cost is greater than the marginal revenue or explains that the profit-maximizing price is $140 (this is the price from the demand curve for the profit-maximizing quantity of 60 units where marginal cost is equal to marginal revenue).

title: Part D
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that the firm has increasing marginal returns and/or does not explain that marginal cost is falling at the quantity of 20 units, indicating that the marginal product is rising.
The response states that the firm has increasing marginal returns and explains that marginal cost is falling at the quantity of 20 units, indicating that the marginal product is rising.

title: Part E
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not identify that the allocatively efficient quantity is 80 units and/or does not explain that allocative efficiency is achieved when the marginal cost to producers equals the marginal benefit to consumers, which occurs where the demand curve intersects the marginal cost curve.

The response identifies that the allocatively efficient quantity is 80 units and explains that allocative efficiency is achieved when the marginal cost to producers equals the marginal benefit to consumers, which occurs where the demand curve intersects the marginal cost curve.
